movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: This is a great movie

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: what went wrong?
review_detailed_main:
This movie is obviously going for a "re-imaging" of Street Fighter. Take a storyline and make it realistically believable. A number of movies adapted from comic books, cartoons and games have succeeded in that aspect; choosing to disregard the more far fetched and fantastical concepts and replacing them with aspects that are more rooted in contemporary reality.

I respect such a decision and who is to dispute it? Previous game adaptations that stuck with its more "unrealistic" concepts(Dead or Alive, Street Fighter 1994) never did as well as those that underwent a realistic re-imaging; like Tomb Raider and Resident Evil. In fact, it would be a breath of fresh air to have a Street Fighter story firmly grounded in reality and without all the campy goofiness that made its predecessor such an embarrassment.

So what went wrong? The story was simple enough to follow. The main character was well developed, as was she good eye candy. The acting was adequate with Neal McDonough giving one fine performance as a screen villain. Intense action and well choreographed fight scenes coupled with all the right camera angles made each battle a treat to watch.

if its one thing that director Andrzej Bartkowiak can do, that is stage a fight and work a camera to bring out the best in that fight scene.(and not surprising since he was originally a cinematographer-turned-director). Each kick and punch is shown with such vivid impact, yet wire stunts and what not are played out with restraint so as to not take away from the realism of the show. Whats more, the director is in familiar territory. With crime syndicate/revenge/martial arts movies like Cradle 2 the Grave and Romeo Must Die in his resume, Legend of Chun Li is right up his alley.

So what went wrong? Indecision. Either it was indecisiveness or a case of "too many cooks spoil the soup".

I bet the producers were split 50/50 on whether to make

a) Make this movie a complete realistic re-imaging or

b) Stick to the far fetched concepts of special powers and "dark qi" and evil organizations bent on world conquest

In the end, they took what could have been one of the MOST grounded-in-reality story for any video game adaptation, and threw in some of the most unbelievable, far out elements from the game. THe movie was going strong until 30 minutes into the film when you see a character tossing a "special power fire-ball" around. Yes i know the game characters tossed special power balls around like pies among clowns but against such a realistic setting and backdrop, such a concept would be ludicrous. Fine, they changed Bison from a power hungry, "psycho power" wielding dictator in charge of his own terrorist nation, into a more realistic underworld crime lord who works through blackmail and subterfuge. Then they had to go and throw in "ancient dark arts to rid a person of his conscience by transferring it into a baby". One of the silliest things i've ever heard; it sounds like something out of a bad 70s cartoon.

Unable to decide if it was going to be a straight out adaptation or a re-imagine, this movie failed to define its target audience and instead delivered a half baked product that was all over the place but not where movie goers want it to be. Overall, it is an entertaining but slightly clichéd cop/criminal organisation/martial arts/revenge story. This movie could have been so much more, but alas, it was not to be. Watch this one just for the fight scenes, and the ever attractive Kristin Kreuk. Way-ta-ruin a movie Capcom and thanks for the fireballs.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Were they TRYING to make an awful movie?

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Stick with the animated movie instead

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Possibly the worst movie to hit the big screen since.....well a while
review_detailed_main:
I would like to start off with a little background, so i don't appear biased. I am a huge movies fan, and will watch almost anything that might be stimulating, and i have been playing video games including street fighter since the first Nintendo entertainment system.

I had seen the original streetfighter, which was just below average, so i was quite happy when they opted to remake it. This was clearly misplaced optimism, the legend of Chun-li is such a poor film, that i consider the fact that it made the big screen, cunning and deceptive.

The movie has the feel of having being shot using an old tea bag as filter, and a camera crew comprising three people. i would even allow Jean-Claude to complain about this movie, because the previous one was better, and that statement speaks volumes

With that said, had the film had it's full compliment of camera crew, it still would not have rescued the weak plot, and even poorer performances. The cast itself was OK, but when you mix underrated actors from your typical blood and guts films, with semi-household names the likes of Michael Clarke Duncan, their average performance resemble the rest of the poor actors.

another corny thing i need to mention, every time Bison alights on the screen, a sound clip or a tiger is played???? HIS NAME IS BISON.

This movie is horrible, really poor, the locations were pretty nice, but that was about it, i was half expecting Steven Seagal to have a Cameo. This movie will cause cataracts

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-literally becoming Caucasian.
review_detailed_main:
Come on! Even if Kreuk is of Asian descent, she's blatantly miscast considering her character is predominantly Asian when portrayed as a young girl (and the source material). Laughably absurd whitewashing aside, this is without a doubt one of the worst video game adaptations I have had the misfortunate of viewing. Did anyone actually try here? It shouldn't be that difficult to make a Street Fighter film, yet this atrocity makes the 1994 adaptation look surprisingly decent (newsflash: it's not). Chun-Li's father is taken by a shadowy organisation who wants to redevelop Bangkok's slums (of all places...) She grows up and naturally seeks revenge by "becoming one with the streets", because y'know...it's Street Fighter.

Punches weaker than Chris "Keanu Reeves" Klein's acting, which literally seems impossible at this stage, and kicks lighter than Kreuk's skin colour, which conversely is entirely possible. There really isn't a redeemable quality to be found. Despite Bartkowiak seemingly trying to direct a relatively mundane plot into a more exciting direction, everything he touches turns to 16-bit nonsense. The inclusion of A-list actors, Clarke Duncan as Balrog and McDonough as an unnecessary Irish Bison, hinders both the film and their careers. Honestly, no one is acting. And it's as if no one has played Capcom's arcade fighter before, as nearly all the characters except Vega are completely wrong.

The plot, characters, score, direction, visual effects, costumes, Chun-Li's hair, fight choreography, my life and dance sequences (no seriously, Chun-Li dances and it's like watching a horror scene) were all the epitome of frickin' boring. Sleep-inducing nonsense. I was howling when Chun-Li kicks the mask of Vega only to reveal, the one and only, Taboo. "I Gotta Feeling" that "Imma Be" using my "Boom Boom Pow" to Hadouken this abomination into a million tiny pieces. "Shut Up", "Rock That Body" and "Pump It" into oblivion. "Where Is The Love" for this rubbish? "Out Of My Head". (Okay, I'm done...).

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Honestly, Is it really that hard to make a good live action Street fighter movie?

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Tomb of the Video Game Adaptation
review_detailed_main:
Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li: 5 out of 10: A Batman Begins style reboot for the Street Fighter series which up to this point consisted of one highly derided film released 15 years earlier.

The Good: You know if you forget this is supposed to be a Street Fighter film (Not hard to do at all since outside of some the character names this really has nothing to do with Street Fighter) this really isn't that bad. Good production values and location shooting with the occasional action beat. Considering this is currently at number 76 of the 100 worst movies of all time on the IMDB list, the low expectations do it some favors as well. Both Kristin Kreuk as the titular star and Moon Bloodgood as a detective are watchable and refreshing. In addition, Michael Clarke Duncan is clearly having fun and his enthusiasm is infectious.

The Bad: Entire doctoral thesis has been written about all the things wrong with the movie. Among the various sins child actors that look nothing like their adult counterparts (to the point of being a clearly different nationality), Chris Klein is awful and drags down every scene he is in, Chris Klein is in way too many scenes, and the villain makes no sense.

The Ugly: Here we get to the crux of the hatred for this unremarkable action film. Street Fighter fans. This is, by any measure, a terrible adaptation of the source material. Now I have to admit my eyes glaze over when rabid fandoms go on the attack because the backstory written to sell some toys and fill five minutes of a twenty-four-minute cartoon is treated as if Moses himself brought it down from the mountain. (I am looking your way Transformers fans), but Street Fighter fans have an understandable beef.

As source material goes Street Fighter is a pretty thin gruel. Unlike many modern video games, Street Fighter has more in common with Pac-Man or Donkey Kong than say The Last of Us. You have colorful characters and a fighting tournament outside of that a screenwriter pretty much has carte blanche to do what he wants with the story. Guess what this movie does not have? If you said a fighting tournament and colorful characters guess what you win a prize.

In Conclusion: Clearly, the screenwriter had a Tomb Raider script sitting in a dusty drawer (The film makes much more sense as a Tomb Raider reboot than a Street Fighter one) and got a call from his agent. Meh, one video game is the same as another just change Lara Croft to Chun Li and change the Irish real estate mogul into Bison and we are good to go. No need to change the plot about the cave of soul cleansing or the mysterious scroll or the heroine living alone in the mansion with servants after her father's disappearance.

Decent B movie action film but in all fairness a horrible adaptation of the source material.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Just not right

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Worst representation of Streetfighter's Chun li
review_detailed_main: I've been a big fan of Chun li since 1994, and Kristen is NOT a good pick to represent Chun li at all! This movie somehow managed to have the weakest plot, poor directing, and bad casting all in one. Aside from having an anorexic actress playing the buff and powerful Chun li, the plot is so unforgivably predictable. At the very end, at least throw us fans a bone and put on the Chun li costum...Go watch this movie if you are NOT a fan of Chun-li, into skinny chick that pretend to throw a punch, bad and predictable plots, shallow and lame character development and BAD acting...Its not even worth it to download it, God forbid if you actually buy the DVD!

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: My Review on Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-li
review_detailed_main: Now, before I had watched this, I read a lot of reviews about the movie. And For some reason the majority of the reviews were harshly negative! Now I just watched it today and to tell you the truth, I went in expecting it to be horrible. But as I watched it I became confused because I was waiting for it to suck big time! But through the whole movie I maintained interest! The movie had a plot and story that kept me hoping that Chun-Li will get her way. I kept wanted to know what would happen next. And I thought the fighting was pretty well done. They made sure to include some of Chun-Li's signature moves which I was excited about and to tell you the truth I thought Kristen Kreuk was a good pick for the part. If you pay attention you realize that in some ways she kinda looks like Chun-Li. Now I had read a review on IMDb saying "Kristen Kreuk managed to turn in the least sexy fighting heroine ever." But you see, I am glad they didn't try to make it all about how sexy Chun-Li is, but more about her and how she became such a great fighter. This movie isn't all about sex and flash. In fact there was only one kissing scene. it was all about Chun-Li! The title explains it! "The Legend of Chun-Li"! not "The Body of Chun-Li" Get a clue people! Now I will admit that I have been a big fan of the game Street fighter ever since i was a kid! When it was first on Nintendo AND I Ain't TALKING ABOUT SUPER NENTENDO! And yes Chun-li was always my fav! So maybe I am a little bias. But isn't that why they made a movie about the game? Because they were fans and wanted to make something for the fans? And of course they would hope to attract some people who may have not played the game before. But if you are going to watch the movie and make a negative review about it because they didn't make her into a sex goddess then maybe you should go find some anime porn! I am sure they have plenty of Street fighter Cartoon porn out there for the masses! I am happy that they made a new movie for the game, and I can't wait for the next one! RYU!!!! WOOT WOOT!

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Be prepared to get surprised.
review_detailed_main:
As you will have or have probably read, almost every single comment on the Internet on this one was negative. At least until stumbling upon it on IMDb, to which to my surprise, had a few positive approaches. The movie's not that bad. It's just like what happened to me before watching Dark Knight: people had pumped it up so much, that when I went to the movies, expecting to see the best picture of my life, what I saw just didn't cut it. Not saying this is the Shawshank Redemption, but hey, if you're a martial arts fan (especially Tai Chi), and if you're a Street Fighter fan to boot, give this one a spin.

Gotta give it to you dissers, Chun Li's special moves look like *crap*.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: It's just... bad.
review_detailed_main:
In the pantheon of movies based on fighting video games you can count on really one to be at least decent if not actually good. And that's the original "Mortal Kombat". While not a masterpiece in any way it still shows decent acting, some good fighting from... most of the people involved and stays reasonably close to the story line.

But that's more or less where it ends. While some might have a soft spot for "Street Fighter" it's not really a good movie but it's high art compared to this trainwreck.

Let me put this out there first. While I think Kristen Kreuk is a lovely woman her acting is atrocious. I'll even forgive them using a white girl to play a Chinese girl as Kristen is part Asian. I can think of a half-dozen other actresses that could have played Chun-Li and would have been much better in the role. But one bad actor shouldn't take away all the fun from a movie so I doubt a better actress would have made it at least watchable.

The story shows us Chun-Li's life from the time she was young to the end when she receives word of another she should meet, namely Ken Masters. But this movie didn't do so great so any chances of a sequel starring Ken or anybody else was cancelled.

The pacing was bad. The acting was bad and the movie was bad.

But to be fair it's not the worst fighting game out there. That goes to Double Dragon.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Confused Movie
review_detailed_main:
Here we have yet another movie that uses the Street Fighter name, yet has no idea who the individual characters are.

Every one, with the exception of Barlog and Vega, were completely out of their " Street Fighter " character .

This movie would have done much better if they dropped the Street Fighter name, and come up with something original.

On it's own, it's an alright martial arts / revenge flick / action genre, nothing spectacular, but still an average B action movie ( better than most of Steven Seagal's movies ).

The good points: Camera work was pretty good. Fight choreography was OK. Set design was good.

The not so good points: The actors were trying, but their deliveries were awkward at times. There are a few plot holes that are never explained. The music at the club scene - WHY did they choose something that BAD? Decisions made by Chun-Li, no real life human would ever do. A lot of padding was used that slows the movie down to a snails pace. Overuse of wire " acrobatics " during combat ( along with pseudo Matrix sound effects thrown in ).

If your in the mood for a generic action movie, and have nothing better to watch, this movie would be perfect for you.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Yup.... Van Damme's was better.
review_detailed_main: Yeah i said it, i freakin loved that movie, but i watch it as if it were a comedy, not a serious SF movie. But this one, MAAANN!! Chris Klein....just stop it. Now, i thought it was bad, but some scenes in the movie i actually perked up, just a tad. They had some story OK, like rose. But so many other mistakes. Like Vega was a very big disappointment. A lot of people complain about Liu Kang, I mean Gen, i didn't think he was that bad. And the fact that (SPOILER DO NOT READ IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO KNOW) Bison dies in the end is pretty disappointing, but in the actual story bison dies and returns a couple times. So, i am just hoping that this sorry excuse for a Street Fighter movie is just a really bad prequel to a very improved sequel. But who knows.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: A case study in over-acting
review_detailed_main:
Seriously...this could be studied in film schools for years to come simply because of the sheer levels of self-seriousness and overly dramatic delivery of the actors. It's bad...really, really bad but it helps the movie in a strange way because you just can't help but laugh at it. The only person who isn't tripping over themselves to deliver this trash is Michael Clarke Duncan...but what do you expect from a man who's usually hired more for his stature than his talent? I'd love to be able to say this was better than the original Street Fighter live action movie, but it's not. Mind you that it's bad for very different reasons, but still...it's pretty lame.

The only thing that really bothered me in this film is the absolutely perverse amount of clichés and the stunning amount of suspension of disbelief required (Kristen Kreuk as a Wushu master? I barely buy her as a human being). Yeah, I realize it's a movie based on a video game, but there's got to be a line somewhere. And if anyone reading this is old enough to remember when Kevin Costner caught all that crap for his on-again-off-again English accent in Robin Hood, then you'll practically die laughing when you hear Neal McDonough lapse in and out of the worst Irish accent I've ever heard...ever ever ever. Oh...and don't forget Chris Klein as the tough Interpol agent who can't stop delivering some of the most ridiculous dialog and one-liners I've ever heard. But the funny thing is that despite all of this the movie manages to at least be watchable. You just can't help but laugh at this stuff and, while that's not it's intention, it doesn't make it any less entertaining. It's a bit of a crap shoot...if you've got something better to watch, go with that. But you might not be as disappointed as you think with this one. It's good for all the wrong reasons.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Thought it was a TV show...that's how bad the acting was.
review_detailed_main: I honestly thought I was watching some low budget TV show. But then it went on for over an hour and a half...so I began to think I was watching a special extra long premiere. Then during commercial break it said something about the Sunday night movie will continue... I couldn't believe that this was an actual movie...as a TV show it was OK but knowing now that this was an actual movie that someone wrote and directed is just disgraceful. I would like to see the street fighter series made for real. This movie would be suitable for teenage kids. But true street fighter fans may want to wait for the real deal to be made.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: I didn't think it was that bad?
review_detailed_main: Not sure what this movie is doing rotting on the bottom 100 list. It isn't too good, but it isn't that bad either. I'm not sure it has much to do with Street Fighter other than a few character names, but it's just a somewhat weak fighting movie. There's not a bunch of cheesy dialogue like the first Street Fighter live action film. No ridiculous characters like that one either. Actors are fine, plot is straight-forward. Maybe it just doesn't seem so bad because I saw 3 other worse movies earlier, all with higher budgets than this. But the worst I can say about this one is that it's just not very interesting. Meh.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Hahaha
review_detailed_main: This made me laugh. This whole thing was useless. If you like long spanned stories with weird business stuff in it, this is for you. Nothing inspired from the games.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: I thought the first one was bad...
review_detailed_main: When producers know that the 1994 movie completely flopped into nothing but an inside joke, they could have turned around and decided to make a serious movie that could have driven the Street Fighter game to new levels, but no, they crapped it all down the tubes. The sequencing is absolutely terrible, they start out with a narrative, and have a few good parts, but then the narrative just keeps going and the movie keeps bogging itself down with very poor wire-stunt work, and some of the worst acting I've ever seen. The "kungfu master" Gen, who is obviously a combined character of Ken and Ryu, has the most cliché dialog ever thought up to go along with his infinitely cliché role. The only really good performances I could find were from Michael Clark Duncan and Neal McDonough. Through out the movie, you could very easily predict what was going to happen several minutes before it actually did. All in all, another depressing look at one of my favorite childhood past-times, put into live action and carelessly flailed across the screen.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Street fighter
review_detailed_main:
Im giving it a 10 just to try and balance out all of the awful reviews.

Costumes are not the same as in the game??? (well that worked for the x-men films, wolverine, yellow spandex anyone,and didn't work in the slightestfor the Van Damme version of street fighter, yeah the costumes were true to the game but in real life they are so very wrong) The costumes in the game are slightly ridiculous so to make any attempt of making this a serious film they had to change that.

Bison is wearing a suit, and has a beard (yes cos most druglords wear military outfit despite not actually being in the military, I see why people would care about that???) Some bad wire work, but lets be honest no worse than in a lot of Chinese films and how else were they gonna recreate moves from the game which are ridiculously over the top in the first place. I thought it was a good effort at bringing those into the film. As for the rest of the action their were some pretty damn good strikes and locks as well really impressive flips, rolls and break falling especially when you consider the main character is from smallville, I was really surprised.

Im surprised at how seriously people criticised this film as well as overacting, I have seen so much worse and at least someone is making street fighter movies. Oh and Chris Klein was in American Pie, so what, also shocked at how many people said this was trash compared with the Van Damme film, I don't think their is one decent martial arts technique in that film, Van Damme did none of the good stuff you see in his older films,the costumes were camp, most of the cast were rubbish in their roles, nothing about that film was good...

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: not that bad!
review_detailed_main: it wasn't that bad. maybe the story was a little different than the game. but still better than the van dammme street fighter movie. at first before it released i thought it was gonna suck ass because ryu wasn't in it. but when i saw the movie and thought about, it makes sense. maybe not perfect but pretty well done movie for an action packed game. at the end of the movie gen speaks about the street fighter tournament and ryu. so there will be a sequel and maybe that one will be even better. so whats up with the disappointment everybody? cheer up. i think this movie deserves good reviews because it wasn't bad as those other game based films like DB:evolution that sucked big time! any way i would recommend everyone to watch this movie.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Hardly a legend
review_detailed_main:
Ever since she was a little girl, Chun-Li's sole ambition in life has been to become a world-class concert pianist. But when her businessman father is unceremoniously whisked away in the middle of the night by a ruthless corporate tycoon bent on ruling the world, Chun-Li agrees to be trained by a martial arts master so she can get her father back and bring the villain's empire crumbling down around him at the same time.

Burdened by kindergarten-level storytelling that makes "Kung Fu Panda" look like stark documentary realism in comparison, "Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li" is a far-from-legendary, barrel-scraping fiasco marked by stock characters, bland performances and rote dialogue.

Heck, even the martial arts sequences fail to generate any genuine excitement or pizazz. Stick to the video game instead. At least you can participate in that one.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Only good thing...
review_detailed_main:
It was miracle that the European boss was Finnish (Sami Vayrynen). So we got to hear few (two lines) of Finnish.

Every other thing falls flat. Chun-Li didn't look like Chun-Li. Gen didn't look like Gen. Bison(Vega) didn't look like Bison(Vega). Vega(Balrog) didn't look like Vega(Balrog). Well Balrog(Bison) so what look like Balrog(Bison), but with others wasn't enough. So casting was off very much.

And ending was disappointing. It left too much open. And same time it reveal too much.

So we are left wait sequel that by my option is going to suck more.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Total piece of junk from stem to stern. Bad casting, but the opening scene is a funny fight.
review_detailed_main: This is a real stinker. The casting for Chun Li is terrible, the girl has tiny arms that can barely lift a tennis ball much less be a convincing fighter. The acrobatic scenes are laughable wire fu/wushu garbage. Chun Li's dad is kidnapped and she sets out for revenge against a super bad guy who has Vega as one of his henchmen. The fight scenes are bloodless and ridiculous, the movie is not true to the video game character.. so anything you came to see is not here.. the lead girl is neither a convincing fighter nor is she hot, she should be both. A twelve year old might like this movie, but I would expect them to have higher standards.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Not even worth a penny!
review_detailed_main:
The movie sucks big time. Being a fan of Street Fighter games, I had high expectations but it all ended within 15 min. I waited desperately for something. And then I was waiting for the movie to get over.

It lack in almost all the departments. The dialogs were worse than even imagined, a 5 yr old could have done better job with it. The direction is so so bad that I would like to request Mr. Andrzej Bartkowiak to please have a disclaimer that it must not be watched.

Lastly, I would just like to highlight my rating that gives 2. The only reason why it doesn't deserve 1 is because of some tolerable action stunts that otherwise are quite normal but for a movie of this low level seems good. So people if you want to be a fan of Street Fighter franchisee please DON'T WATCH THE MOVIE>

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: (Unintentionally) The Comedy Of The Year!
review_detailed_main:
You know how they say that some movies are so bad that they're good? Well, "Street Fighter: The Legend Of Chun-Li" may be so brain-boilingly awful that it's actually incredible. Take pretty much everything that you know about the video game this is based on, and throw it all out of the window because that's exactly what the makers of this movie did!

Now have a think about the following question. If you had been orphaned as a small baby in Thailand, what accent would you have after growing up there? Well, according to the makers of this movie, it would be Irish. If you're looking for an explanation to this, the movie intelligently provides one by informing you that the character in question (Bison, for those of you who know your Street Fighter games) had an Irish mother.

Erm...right!

This is a movie in which we have a renegade cop called Nash who has obviously never had the time to look up the word 'cliche'. With two day stubble, he swaggers around his scenes shouting things like "What orders?" or growling at computer screens. At one point he walks straight up to the camera to recite plot-moving dialogue straight to the audience with a knowing wink.

This movie is awful. Absolutely terrible. There is even a scene in which Chun Li actually has a sexy dance-off with a lesbian enemy. I swear to God, that I'm not joking about this. What's even better is that this scene ends with a character asking renegade cop Nash 'Are you going to tell me or should I guess?' with Nash growling back in a Dirty Harry voice (whilst squinting like somebody playing a parody in one of those "Epic Movie" abominations) 'Go ahead and guess.' It's as though Chris Klein (who plays Nash) was the only actor who realised that this entire movie was a joke and decided to pretend he was in a comedy.

I can't recommend this movie enough if you get any amusement over cinematic car crashes.

Terrible. Just terrible.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Bold but True Statement - Worse than the First

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Okay. It's not a glam action movie, in now way. But, it's got some good scene's in it...
review_detailed_main: Okay, just watched this movie(As I also watched the original, with JCVD, when I was a kid.). Trust me, it's not worth the trip to the theater's, that's for sure. Now, with that said. Let me break it down a bit here. It is NOT an all out martial art's fighting style of movie. And, here is actually why many people let it go over their head's(Because, I have seen many of these type's of spin-off's. If you want a better idea, of why I say it's a "spin-off" & a cliche' style of a backtrack to the first movie &/or the game. It may not be a game. But, it does refer to the background's of the original character's, of the original movie's. Check on the movie "Logan", in reference to where Wolverine, from the X-Men came from. It's not an all out battle and special FX through the whole movie. It's your basic dull climb to where the original could actually begin, or start from.). Okay, to not give away any spoiler's, the plot that seem's choppy to most and a downer, to them. Is actually set on the beginning of the lives of certain character's, like Chun-Li(AKA Chun-Lee, if you seen the name, in I think 2 of the original game's, for the Nintendo, or Super Nintendo. I forget which one, though.), Bison & Vega. Before she get's the dual side hair bun's and her infamous dress, that you see her fighting in, in the game's. It's basically, an intro, to the possibilities of the original. Kinda like the Star War's movie's. How, they made them, like 30 years, AFTER the original trilogy. To me, they were cheesy and dull. But, what do you expect, from an intro style movie!? Where, the character's, don't really know, who they really are, yet? It's kinda like a right of passage, to give a background story, on the character's, themselves, to let people see, where they came from(Exactly the same thing, that they were doing, with the X-Men movies. When, they spawned the Wolverine side movies. And, those, after the first, weren't too bad. But, the first of those spawn's, was dull as a marble. But, it set the ground, of where to take the next sequel that would eventually, lead up to the original movie.). So, I wasn't expecting the tournament style fighting. But granted, I did expect some better acting. But, it didn't seem like the actor's were really at fault. I have seen many of the actor's/actresses in other movie's/show's. And, they did much better work in those. So, it seemed like they were at a loss, of which way to turn, without their leader(The producer, to tell them, what they needed, for the scene to look more realistic.). As if, the producer, just told them, to ad-lib half the movie. Where, they kept bumpin their head's, a lot, when they should have been more in-sync, then tryin to cross each other's path's. Now, most of the fight scene's were pretty good, like I said. Where, the obvious best, were between Robin Shou(Loved him, as Liu Kang, in the original & sequel of Mortal Kombat.) & Kristin Kreuk. And, the fight in the girl's restroom, with Josie Ho & Kristin Kreuk, wasn't bad, either. But, there are a few other good short fight's, where it makes it worth while, to get the cheap seat's, for the movie. I would bet, if they had a different producer, that knew what they were doing, it could have gotten a 7 or 8, or maybe a 9, instead of the 5 star...

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Typical, thoughtless, gamer movie

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Great performance by Kristin Kreuk and Neal McDonough

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: OK, it has not much to do with the game Street Fighter, but...
review_detailed_main:
I tend to make it a habit to vote on IMDb after I've seen a movie, and usually I'm pretty spot on with the grade I have in my mind compared to the average here. I did expect to be voting above average this time, but I didn't expect the average to be this low.

True, during the movie there were quite a few moments that I had to laugh because of predictable, or over the top things, but I expect that from a movie based on a game which is over the top by itself. Now it's also true that the story hasn't got much in common with the game story, but I also think the game story isn't that extraordinary to care for it. Perhaps they could have called it differently, and use different names. I had not problems putting it aside.

Anyway, when I started this movie I was expecting something bad, but I was in the mood for something bad with over the top martial arts. Unexpectedly, something about the movie just grabbed me. Even though the plot is not spectacular, it was definitely not unwatchable. Most modern action movies have me lose my attention soon, because of their simplicity. They usually just dump a handful of characters on your screen, tell you who's good, who's bad and then let you watch two hours of constant running and fighting. In this case they did seem to wanna try and tell the story, and not just put a bit of story in there to justify the fighting, so I guess that made the difference for me.

Compared to the 1994 Street Fighter I think it's a lot better, even though that's not very hard to do. 6.5/10 rounded up.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: A golden opportunity wasted

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: The 1994 movie is a masterpiece compared to this trash!! Avoid!!

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Uh,,, great cast at least,,,
review_detailed_main: By NO means is this a GOOD movie,, and that's a shame. Kristin Kruek is the PERFECT actress to play Chun Li!! With a different director and better writers this probably could've been something incredible. Oh well. If you want to turn off your brain and watch a movie,, this'll do.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Definition of a bad crossover.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: It's impressive how this terrible movie makes the outrageous cheese of the 1994 Van Damme film look like a masterpiece.
review_detailed_main: Two stars might be generous for this one, but I had a fun theater experience laughing with my friends at how unabashedly awful this movie was. Movies like this are why video game adaptations have such a bad reputation. Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li tried to make a gritty, more realistic version of the games while simultaneously using every cheesy cliche they could imagine. I can go down the list from there on how bad the acting, stunts, fighting, and costumes were. This movie felt like a bad straight-to-TV movie directed by the B-team at the CW. The crazy thing is that Capcom was heavily involved in this film and still let this disaster see the light of day. Hopefully, it's been long enough for a Street Fighter reboot to make its way to the silver screen once again.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: What Did You Expect For A Fantasy B Grade Movie?
review_detailed_main:
I give a five out of ten because it is a cheesy B grade movie so why judge it like a higher grade movie? To me the biggest draw backs is the writing, acting, and directing has many signs of weakness throughout the movie. On the other hand the over all production gives it a glossy appearance of oa much better movie so it's not like the cheesy martial arts movies in the past.

The fight scenes is about what you'd expect. People getting hits that cripple or kill most people only these people keep coming back for more. On the other hand the gun scenes get even more ridiculous because even automatic weapons just can't hit some people. That's something I've seen in too many comic book heroes portrayed on TV. When mere humans outrun automatic fire....Ya! That's pure bull...

It's worth at least five stars because in the end...You watch it because sometimes you like a cheesy B movie just for kicks....And this does deliver.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: I feel bad for Kristin Kreuk

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: You really need to be a Street Fighter fan
review_detailed_main:
As a huge Street Fighter fan since childhood, I couldn't leave out this movie despite all the bad reviews.

The script is cringeworthy at times, but there is some surprisingly good dialogue still: "as time went by I was getting further and further away from all I ever was, I felt lost chasing a ghost I might never find."

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Am I the only one here who actually likes this movie?

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: You said it's bad, i says it's worth.
review_detailed_main:
How the bad thing become a worst? Ask Michael Bays, he answered with transformer 2. On Legend of Chun Li, you'll see the bad movies chemical inside struggling it self to be unrecognized.

The Bad become only bad.

And it is worth for mediocre motion pictures for gamers freak. At last, this movies surpasses the shitty legacy of JCVD's Street Fighter. I vote it 7 stars, for being decent movies, the fight, the breast cleavages, and the non-English words. At least major police station in Bangkok didn't placed at the cheap showrooms. Last, i think they take it seriously to doing something for uneasy story like Street Fighter's. It become bad, but i gave them salute.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: "Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li"- Basically every bland 90's direct-to-video action-flick, but with an actual budget and an inexplicable theatrical release.
review_detailed_main:
Honestly, perhaps the most perplexing thing about 2009's "Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li" is just how completely and utterly average a movie it really is. It's basically completely sanitary and relatively inoffensive in its structuring, with just competent enough production values and a generally passable cast. But it's so plain and "blah," you can't help but feel yourself starting to nod off should you chose to give it a watch. And I think that's the real problem. It's not the terrible crime against film that it's made out to be... it's just so wholly unremarkable as a movie-going experience, that it feels empty and pointless.

It really does remind one of those cheap-o 90's direct-to-video action flicks that used to pollute the video-store shelves back in the day. This feels like the sort-of film you'd rent on a whim because it looks like it might be good for a laugh, watch on a Friday night and forget about a day later. The sort of film Z-grade actors like Antonio Sabato Jr. or Cynthia Rothrock would pop up in and kick some butt while a cheesy synth soundtrack blared in the background. But inexplicably, this one somehow got a theatrical release, a $50 million budget and was tied in to a popular tournament-fighter video-game series. Unfortunately, unlike the other "Street Fighter" live-action adaptation, which at least was semi-comedic and benefited from campy laughs and a great performance by the late Raul Julia... "The Legend of Chun-Li" is just boring and mind-numbing in its standardness.

The film follows one of the characters from the "Street Fighter" game series, Chun-Li. When she was only a child, she witnessed the kidnapping of her father by the dreaded M. Bison. Years later, after losing her mother to cancer, she encounters martial-arts master Gen, and trains under him, vowing to get vengeance for her father's abduction. And so, the film degenerates into a standard tale of action and revenge as our heroine faces various thugs and obstacles in her struggles against Bison and his cronies. Yawn.

It shouldn't be too surprising that the film is helmed by Polish cinematographer-turned-director Andrzej Bartkowiak. After all, he was already responsible for another extremely bland and toothless video-game adaptation in "Doom", and this film falls into many of the same trappings as that release. Inspired by a video-game source material yet afraid to follow the details and formula of the original work. Filled with lots of high-concept ideas but a slave to clichés. Cast with generally decent performers who are hampered by sub-par screen writing. And assembled with relative competence while simultaneously feeling generic and trite. While Bartkowiak's films might not be as ludicrously awful as other, more infamous video-game movie directors (I'm looking at you, Uwe Boll), in a way, his films are worse. At least the poorer films generate some talking points due to their overt failures... Bartkowiak's are merely wholly forgettable.

To give credit where it is due, the film does have some minor strengths. I really liked some of the supporting cast for one. It was really great seeing "Mortal Kombat" star Robin Shou back on the screen as martial-artist Gen, and he's a criminally underrated and highly likable actor. It was also good fun seeing the late Michael Clarke Duncan as one of Bison's main cronies. Some of the action was appropriately thrilling and the effects were generally passable. And there's even a few really fun, schlock-tastic instances of blood and gore in the Unrated version of the film that generate an appropriately queasy response.

But the script by Justin Marks is the most basic of the basic, the cinematography is flat and uninspired and lead actress Kristin Kreuk is hilariously un-charismatic, leaving the film just feeling dull. Not terrible. Just dull and average at best. There was really no reason this film should have been tied to "Street Fighter" besides brand recognition, and it could just have easily been re-written to be an "original" story. The purported $50 million is barely visible on- screen and could easily have been slashed in half. And the movie really didn't warrant a release on the big-screen. This really is just about on- par your standard direct-to-video action-thriller. And that's where it should have been released. At least then, I would have known to set my standards a bit lower.

"Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li" is a 4 out of 10. If you catch it on cable and there's nothing else on, give it a shot. It'll at least kill 90 minutes on a slow afternoon. But if you're thinking about actually paying to rent or buy it, don't bother.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: A waste of a perfectly good movie.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Such a great fun-bad movie
review_detailed_main: They completely change the characters origin, then the movie follows a story that would make sense to the original origin. Every change to the story they made made their movie more convoluted. Amazing.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: A steaming turd of unparalled proportions
review_detailed_main: I once wrote that 'Batman& Robin' was the worst movie ever made, boy was I wrong! Street Fighter: Legend of Chun-Li is worse, so much so that my eyes actually started to bleed whilst watching it. The film bears little to no resemblance to the story or characters of the video game for which it was based, instead it plods away at a suicidally slow pace whilst throwing in every cliché and corny line that it can muster. I can't say that i've heard of Chris Klein but i can tell you this....... Chris Klein desperately needs acting lessons - had they hired a tone deaf mute with one leg and no fingers, i'm pretty sure he would have done a better job in the role, this man made me want to actually pour acid into my eyes rather than watch him for one more second. For the first hour of the film, nothing happens then when the last forty minutes of eyeball torture comes around......nothing happens. Basically the film is a big bundle of nothingness, wrapped in a tea cosy of nothingness......shrink wrapped in nothingness for good measure. Save yourself one hour and forty minutes of your life by avoiding it like you would a vat of aids or a politician.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: And people claim Street Fighter is bad?. Trust me, this is much worse!.
review_detailed_main:
I actually enjoy the original Street Fighter, for what it is, but this on the other hand, is a piece of garbage, that has all the fun taken out of it. I dig Neal McDonough, but he plays a terrible Bison, with a horrific accent!. The fights are filled with nothing but people on wires, and fancy looking stunts, where as the original actually had some Realness to it!. The cast in the original was a lot of fun. They weren't the best actors, but they were fun to watch, in this movie they all take it seriously, and that's what really killed it in the end for me, along with the terrible acting. I realize this movie is not based on the original, but it's missing all the key characters, that made the original so much fun in a cheesy way. The movie relies heavily on the development of Kristen Kruek, aka Chun Li. Her character is interesting, but not interesting enough to focus an entire movie on her revenge plot. The people who complain about how bad Street Fighter is, I suggest you take a look at this movie. You may think twice, about calling that one bad.

Performances. Kristin Kreuk is pretty, and her performance ranges from weak, to above average. Here she is riddled with inconsistency. She clearly gives it her all, but the movie isn't good enough to support her. Chris Klein is an actor, I actually like, but his wooden, cocky performance here, does not do the movie any favors, what's with the hair do?. Neal McDonough is terrible as Bison. He looked like he was having fun, but I didn't have fun hearing that god awful accent, and he's certainly no Raul Julia. Robin Shou isn't bad, but his charisma can only take the role so far. Michael Clarke Duncan has spirit, I'll definitely say that much. Moon Bloodgood is good eye candy, but that's about it.

Bottom line. This is the pure definition of a clunker. There are no redeeming qualities about the movie, nor is there much entertainment value at all. It's a rather dull 90 minutes of your life, that you can spend much better elsewhere, Avoid.

2/10

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: It's not Street Fighter, and it absolutely has nothing to do with Chun-Li or the fighting game itself
review_detailed_main:
Honestly I have nothing more to say about this awful movie. I myself have actually enjoyed playing Street Fighter games because their movesets are very simple to pull off and most of it's roster just has the perfect kind of appearance they would also look for most of Capcom's gaming lineup.

So this is based on Street Fighter's iconic female fighter Chun-Li, this movie is focused around her and the revenge she gets at M. Bison for killing her father. And asides that this movie tries so hard to explain her story throughout the film, it seems to fall off so hard and panned.

The casting is pretty god-awful and horrible and it seems to me like they added Kristen Kreuk to play as Chun-Li. Even though she was a lot better playing as Lana Lang in Smallville, I feel that her role as the popular female fighter is an absolute mis-cast because she happens to be a mixed-race (she is Chinese Canadian) for the Street Fighter character who is fully Chinese, at one point in this movie she puts on her trademark hairbuns and wears a blue dress (not even a qipao), but then the rest of this movie shows her wearing black or other clothing that doesn't match Chun-Li at all. Neal McDonough is even worse for playing as M. Bison because he looks nothing like his video game counterpart, doesn't even wear his iconic outfit, at least Raul Julia had dark hair for the role of M. Bison back when he played as him before his death. Although we can safely say that Julia's role of the villain had more better experience than that of McDonough who's hardly even acted out like Bison especially with that dumb fake Scottish or Irish accent. Chris Klein and Moon Bloodgood that both played as Charlie Nash and Maya (who is basically C. Viper from SFIV) don't even look like their video game counterparts and just go off as useless detectives in scenes from this movie. They're using guns most of the time and I don't know if they would've known that this movie is called Street Fighter and they should've been using their hand-to-hand combat besides using firearms for most of the movie. Two other one of Bison's Shadaloo men Balrog and Vega were played by the late Michael Clark Duncan and Taboo (singer of the Black Eyed Peas). Both of their roles also had major flaws. For Duncan on his role as Balrog goes off using firearms and can't even throw punches at one of his opponents just because he's a boxer. For Taboo on his role as Vega shows that he's too short to play the role and is also Native-Mexican while Vega in the games is actually tall and Spaniard. Overall the one interesting role I would somewhat like is Robin Shou who you might remember him as Liu Kang in Mortal Kombat from 1995 and plays a small role as a pirate leader in DOA: Dead or Alive. He plays the role of Gen who is Chun-Li's master and spends his time training and also fighting alongside with her in the movie. The one thing that throws me off is when he pronounces Ryu as RAI-YOO and not REE-YOO or if you were to roll that "R" with the name it would've sounded more accurate.

The fight scenes in this movie somehow feel ok at times but then they would show the scene where Chun-Li would actually kill one of those guys in this movie especially when she's a police officer! And not only that, there are some brutal scenes that make it a little hard to watch just because they would slap on the Street Fighter name on the title of this film!

The special effects in this movie are absolutely the worst ones yet. There are times when you know that the bullet shots are digital effects without using prop firearms. And the Kikoken scene is the most terrible cheap special effect of all-time. It's not even colored blue like in the games, and the appearance on it looked like it was taken from an old 90s computer graphics that still looks awful today.

The quotes in this movie are probably the worst, no where near as corny as what we usually would hear in Street Fighter the Movie with JCVD and Raul Julia. That movie at least was cheesy and had fun moments which still shows some better word quotes from characters like Guile like when he gives out a speech or M. Bison talking about raiding Chun-Li's village ending with the phrase "For me, it was Tuesday". But in Legend of Chun-Li, it seems their lines were murky and also uninspired like Bison would tell Chun-Li that her father is the milk of his business and would finish with "But even milk has an expiration date". I mean how would you not know that milk goes bad all the time! Especially all the other characters quotes feel so flat and terrible in terms of a scene they would be mentioning.

Ok so this movie of it's own would think that Rose (and yes I'm talking about Rose from Street Fighter games) is the daughter of M. Bison. There is no blood-related connection between them in the games. Rose is in fact Italian from the fighting game she originates and has a fortune telling ability. This movie's version of (White) Rose is nothing more than coming off as Russian (due to the language she spoke) and is never actually a fighter.

Overall this movie is nothing more than a pretty bad reception and a god-awful superhero like fighting game adaptation. Everything about this movie is so bland, most of the characters in this movie don't even look or dress like their appearances from the video games because they're all wearing black for the majority of the film, the special effects are all so cheaply made like it's an independent movie despite being released by 20th Century Fox (now known as 20th Century Studios), the acting and writing is so piss-poor with each character's lines saying something nonsensical, and all about this movie is that they were planning to have a sequel with Ryu and Ken Masters. Unfortunately it didn't happen and I'm just so glad that the sequel of this misstep of an adaptation would never have been made, it could've been much worse.

This movie's runtime is about 96 minutes, well apparently the deleted scenes included multiple scenes that were cut from the final product! One being a cameo scene with the producer of Hyde Park Entertainment, Ashok Amritraj. And at the very end is suppose to be I think a post-credit scene where the White Rose is at the police station then all of a sudden her eyes show that she's possessed almost thinking she's taken M. Bison's aura around her. But again overall I'm just glad that a sequel had to be cut out for this abomination.

It's hard to believe that the writer for this movie would later go on to write the live action Disney Jungle Book movie from 2016 and of course probably the best drama movie of all-time, Top Gun Maverick! It's incredible he went from a rocky start to a smooth flowing safe trail. I recommend watching those movies instead, but stay FAR AWAY FROM LEGEND OF CHUN-LI!! I recommend axing it or Hadouken it in flames!

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Not the worst movie I've seen
review_detailed_main:
The plot is pretty loose: kidnapping, some almost spiritual journey to beat the bad guys without being angry, some random sub-plot about the "white rose" which didn't add much/make much sense, in my opinion.

Fight scenes were pretty standard for poorly rated martial arts films. Also included some pointless Matrix-style stunts.

There were a few actors I recognised but this film didn't do much for them. It was all pretty cringe.

I especially find films that insert themselves into another culture, especially commenting on that country's politics/social issues, are even worse when they use mostly American actors.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: A kick ass movie with a story!
review_detailed_main:
I totally disagree with those negative reviews!

I just came back from watching "Street Fighter: Legend of Chun Li" at the cinema and the movie is better than my expectation! Way much better than the 1st movie which was so lame to watch even on DVD! I'm not an ardent fan of the game but I'm familiar with the characters and Chun Li is my favorite kick-ass heroine. Kristin Kreuk did a pleasant job as Chun Li!

My salute to the production team and the director for keeping the spirit of the story/game. It may not be the best action movie but certainly a good kick ass movie with a story that worth your money! So why are you still reading this review at home/work?! Go and watch the movie at the cinema now...wherever you are!!!!!!

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: More than I had expected
review_detailed_main:
It's historical that most movie adaptions that are based on games have a poor history. Some take the comical route as did "Double Dragon", which went well in my eyes when I saw it as an early teenager - I would find a lot more to bash about it today, some were written with monkeys with down syndrome; Mortal Kombat: Annihilation, case in point, and others veered from the original idea to form their own story; Resident Evil.

The original "Street Fighter" was terrible; now comes "legend of Chun Li". To be honest I didn't know what to expect and I merely wanted it for my collection - just another DVD I could poke fun at with friends down the road. Though not perfect, I found this to be far more entertaining than I was going to give it credit for. I didn't find any overly-drawn out romance scenes, I didn't notice any over the top special effects or special moves (Though I did recognize some of the fighting moves as those found in the various "Street Fighter" games) and just about everything is almost plausible as far as realism in the fighting.

Also to note, I don't feel any one character was over-cast or added in "just because" as was the case with "Mortal Kombat: Annihilation" (take Rain for instance). Vega only has a handful of scenes, Balorg is merely the Hench man without much dialog to screw up, and the only other character besides Bison is Chun Li herself (obviously) and Gen (acting as mentor).

I laughed at some of the attacks, like Chun Li's spin-kick, but moments like that were too far between for me to seriously point out as down grading the movie. Also it almost gave me a toned-down "Kill Bill" feel, and while I won't reveal any real spoilers, I would like to address that this movie is probably to date, one of the rare gems that don't put shame the title it's representing ("Street Fighter").

The movie does end with an opening, suggesting there may be sequels or a franchise (I can only speculate that the series would, if pursued, will follow the likely trend of drifting down hill). It does have some dialog that is pretty stock and uninspiring, but I can't really downgrade my rating based solely on that.

With all the Hollywood adaptions of popular themes (Transformers, Terminator, X-Men, etc), they could have done far worse with this movie than they did.

You can't please the fans, they will always find something to complain about (I'm a "Street Fighter" fan and I could have found lots to bash), so I take a step back and review it if I were going into this movie without a clue about "Street Fighter", and the result is, while not perfect, it's not a bad flick. I'll end this by saying, watch this with an open mind and average expectations and you will find an enjoyable 97mins.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: A Decent Martial Arts Revenge Actioneer (Unrated Version)

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Truly not the best but not the worst either.
review_detailed_main:
STREET FIGHTER: THE LEGEND OF CHUN LI starts with a young Chun Li whose father gets kidnapped by M. Bison and Barog, years later Chun LI is all grown up and sets out on a journey to bangkok to find a warrior named Gen who will show her a way to defeat Bison and get her father back.

This game to film adaptation is directed Andrej Bartowiak, whose credits includes more superior fare such as ROMEO MUST DIE, EXIT WOUNDS, CRADLE 2 THE GRAVE and the game to film adaptation of DOOM, although this film is not the director's best work but it is far from being the worst movie ever made, this adaptation is mostly reinvented, the characters are portrayed differently such as Vega who in the game wears a mask to protect his looks, in this film he wears a mask to hide his identity, none of the things that were attempted in this film were meant as bad intentions, it was a case of the filmmakers maybe wanting to give STREET FIGHTER fans something different, only it wasn't very well received.

The acting isn't all bad but not all good, seeing Chris Klein as Nash who is a cocky police detective, you kind of figure someone needed to tell him that he didn't need to make it so obvious that he was acting lame, Robin Shou who plays Gen is not a bad actor but here he's a bit wooden as if he didn't have much to work with, the rest of the cast did all right, but Chris Klein doesn't fit in with his role.

On the Positive side there are a few good fight scenes and a strong female lead, its truly not the best action film you'll find but at least it won't join the same list as the game to film disasters of Uwe Boll.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: critics don't know a good movie when they see one!
review_detailed_main: This was a good movie I don't understand why people are hating on it so much. Just don't watch it expecting it to be the standard Street Fighter plot because it's not. This movie is not about entering a tournament and competing against other fighters instead it just focuses on the character Chun-Li's story. Rather then being a fighting movie it struck me as more of an action film. The cast was great and perfect for each character they played. Sure there was some fighting in there it could have had a little more fighting scenes but other then that I really enjoyed it. The explosions and gun fire makes up for the lack of choreography even though there is a few decent fighting scenes anyways. From the way they ended this it looks like they are going to make a sequel and if that happens id definitely pay to see it. At least they aren't painting the same picture over and over again because the standard fight in a tournament film has been done too many times and it's good when they throw some action into the mix like they did here. I gave this one an 8/10 because I really enjoyed it.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: entertaining movie
review_detailed_main: I don't personally care if a movie follows a comic or a video game accurately. I don't play games or read comics so others might have different opinions. I really liked street fighter: the legend of Chun-Li. It was better than i thought it would be and it had a lot of action. I recommend seeing it if your looking for an entertaining action movie with some cool martial arts. I liked the characters and thought it was better than the van-damn version. It was a good movie. I thought it was cool how they controlled energy and showed a little power. I also liked how cops were involved. I don't think it was bad that they used the actors they did.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Good and Bad are so wonderfully blurred
review_detailed_main:
I think you should give this movie a chance if you're unsure.

I liked this movie for the horrible acting by Chris Klein you can't help and laugh at everything he says and does. However his horrible acting made everyone else look good comparably! I thought Kristin Kreuk was adorable, Robin Shou was totally believable (after all he was in the mortal combat movies), and Neal McDonough makes such a great bad guy. I recommend this movie to people who know how to find the good in bad movies and how to love the bad parts equally.

I would have loved to see what happened next but I have a feeling they won't make a second one.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: better than most of the game to movie adaptations
review_detailed_main: I read some of the comments and I must say I don't agree that the movie is bad. After watching so many ultra bad adaptations of games to movies, I didn't feel bad about this movie at all. I am not saying this is a master piece or something like that but come on, it deserves much better than 3.9. I guess they failed with the marketing. Otherwise, there was no substantial problem. Some people still couldn't understand how to evaluate a movie. This is a game adaptation. Characters were good, plot was OK (except these police guys that didn't have any influence on the story), directing was quite good and the overall performance was better than average. Chun-Li fights exactly the way it was shown, some of the street fighter characters were there and most importantly they at least stick to the general plot of the game. If you remember Max Payne for example, the movie had nothing to do with the game, yet it was never evaluated as harsh as this one. I am giving a 7 because the movie deserves a 7 from my point of view. If you don't know anything about Street Fighter, the plot may look strange. But apart from that, if you ever played the game, you are likely to enjoy the movie.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Best Street Fighter Movie ever
review_detailed_main:
Honestly, what is there not to love in this Street Fighter movie.... Kristin Kreuk.... Chris Kline.... Moon Bloodgood.... It is the best comedy I have seen in a long time.

Chun-li is a fragile little dumpling that somehow becomes strong enough to destroy Bison. The most priceless thing is how Chris Klein walks around posing and squinting half the time and trying to act sexy, and always giving zoolander Blue Steel looks. It's hilarious. The conversation between him and Moon bloodgood is also so funny. They try to turn each other on, but it's like watching a bad 90's sitcom. This movie is the perfect combination of pathetic and failed franchize all in one....but Kristin Kreuk is good to look at ....especially when she is dancing in the club and trying to trap the lesbian 50year-old crime boss. I can't...this movie is too good!

Oh...and did I mention Robin Shou's bad make-up to make him look older? He looks like an old man had too much plastic surgery.

Watch the movie and have an amazing time :)

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Admirable effort
review_detailed_main:
The Legend of Chun Li takes a vastly different approach to the Street Fighter franchise compared to the 1994 film. It focuses more on a single character and tries to depict her as well as her adversaries as interesting characters with history. The effort is admirable though doesn't work perhaps completely all the way through.

After a fairly strong beginning the second act of the film deteriorates a little bit. The section following Chun Li's life in Bangkok suffers from some shotty editing and skipping between unrelated events. The feeling of a coherent transition is lost because of this. The film also makes the faux pas of redundant flashback usage in a 90 minute film.

However, the effort seen in the dialogue scenes of the film's shows that this is clearly trying to be different from most other video game movies. Sadly the Doom-director's natural ability for action-scenes doesn't lend much here and a few of the scenes feel sobby and forced. But at least the film made the effort.

Over-all the actor performances for the more recognisable characters are all solid and only Charlie stands out as being a clichéd character-type. The action-scenes look excellent and if the dialogue scenes were a little bit more involved then the movie would certainly earn praise.

Even as it is, the film is good and worth a watch, but I personally always preferred the entertainment value of the 1994 film more.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Great movie
review_detailed_main: This was a great movie and who underrates it?? If only it hit the theaters... I've watched this movie so many times that I actually have to buy another dvd of it cause the other was scratched. Kristin is always such a great character in every movie and my fave.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Its not a bad film, just a bad conversion
review_detailed_main:
Being a film lover, and even being able to enjoy watching even a good B movie, I rate this as a better than average game conversion movie.

It has a nice budget, plenty of action, a story than generally makes sense, some fairly well known faces and even starts off fairly promising.

The main rub is that it tries to make the film appear almost every-day believable, which just doesn't work with it also trying to be a totally fictional game conversion where there are special powers all over the place.

Toning down certain abilities, and omitting characters from the game will always upset hardcore gaming fans, which is a shame as the film really isn't all that bad.

My biggest bug-bear is the directing. If you are going to do an action movie then pick an action director and style it that way, but if you are going to try and throw in romance, military and martial arts as well then at least pick a director who has a familiarity with those genres.

What you get here is a film that works in places but fails in others, because the director has no idea of how to shoot scenes with police or the armed forces and yet insist on including them in the plot. Mistake!

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Impressive
review_detailed_main: I heard a lot of bad reviews but I honestly think that this movie doesn't deserve it. Chun-Li was always my favourite character and to see a film just of her was so entertaining. I watched it when it first came out and I'm watching it again. It's better now. And Vega and Chun-Li always had bad blood. It's fun to watch them fight.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Hmmmmm ... completely brainless, but... judge for your selves
review_detailed_main:
The plot and the dialogs are idiotic and I can not stress this enough, they are really moronic. However the action sequences are entertaining and the lead actresses are good looking.

So if you are able to completely switch off your brain for an hour and a half, you just might get some mild entertainment from this action flick.

Other than that, there isn't much else to say about this movie, they fight, but the fights have no meaning for the story, some of the characters don't develop at all and others develop in an irrational way. The movie has no real point other than to obviously jump start a series, but honestly with such a lame start I can't see how it would do that.

It's sort of like "Knight Rider" the start of the new series, only much worse.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Simply better than a '3.9'
review_detailed_main:
I was rather shocked to see a 3.9 for this title. When I reviewed the voting record the truth was revealed -- about 1/4 of the people that bothered to rate the film rated it a '1'. Some angry / jealous Virtua-Fighter fans maybe...? A movie would have to be truly horrible to garner a 1 from me, not just have a 'score I disagreed with that needed lowering' as many dishonest IMDb idiots appear to vote at times.

Of course it wasn't a 'great' movie, and in fact seems best suited for people that are either huge fans of Kristen Kruek (KK) and / or Street Fighter. I liked it well enough to post a '6', but admittedly I'm a big KK fan from her Smallville work.

The flow was good, and it was cast well all around -- as well as can be expected for a movie cast from a video game with virtually .no. plot to it. Arguably KK doesn't have the quads to play a live-action version of Chun-Li, but in my eyes her very decent acting made up for that.

The plot had some unexpected happiness within it also and that became what I cherished most about it.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: it was OK? okish

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: It's about The Angry White Man
review_detailed_main: This movie should have been entitled "The Angry White Man" because the main character is a nasty white man who is angry and is determined to act out his nastiness in Bangkok, Thailand, which far from appearing exotic, looked a lot like a combination of downtown Los Angeles and midtown New York City. The other characters serve peripheral roles and, with the exception of Michael Clarke Duncan who plays Mr. Bison's henchman, all of them are quite unspectacular, some being outright ludicrous. The young lady playing the street fighter is utterly miscast and her mentor-friend is equally out of place in this otherwise interesting if not overly impressive movie. The movie does have its good moments but only when Mr. Bison or Mr. Duncan are in the scene. Mr. Bison is the only character which is developed in the movie, the others being mere caricatures of good guys or bad guys. A good performance is given by Mr. Duncan who could have played the lead villain too. Mr. Duncan deserves kudos for his performance.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: It's not really as awful as the rating would suggest
review_detailed_main:
No, it's not amazing and no the story is not an emotional journey that makes you both laugh and cry... but.

It's a video-game adaption, and you really can't go in to them thinking they are gonna blow your socks off because really, most of them aren't that great.

The 1994 Jean Claude Van Damme adaption was genuinely awful and that was pretty true to the (no) plot of the video-game so of course they had to do something different here, which I am glad they did, not just fighting all the time but an actual story.

Now of course the story does have a bunch of plot holes (but honestly what video-game adaption that doesn't?) and Chris Klein's acting in particular is pretty dodgy, he plays a tough guy cop which he tried to do again in CAUGHT IN THE CROSSFIRE (2012) but he fails every time.

I like him fine usually but yeah he's not at all believable as a 'bad ass'.

Better is Kristin Kreuk in the lead and Michael Clarke Duncan and Neal McDonough are pretty cool as the bad guys.

And most of the fight-scenes are pretty well orchestrated (except perhaps the dance-club scene) and the cinematography is good and keeps at a good pace plus a pretty good soundtrack as well.

All in all, not a 'great film' but perfectly watchable if you leave your thinking cap on the shelves and just take it for what it is, if you enjoyed ELEKTRA (2005) you should be able to enjoy this... If you didn't (which granted many didn't) then tread carefully I suppose.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: No ethical background but great movie
review_detailed_main: This is really nice movie it has all the right ingredients with fighters and all this kind of things and it's definitely interesting enough so why the low points are definitely wouldn't know and all these things are definitely great but it can be said this movie unfortunately does not have the right ethical background.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: I Enjoyed it.
review_detailed_main: Great fight scene's, acting was good. English was great. I enjoyed the movie.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: entertaining and not bad
review_detailed_main: I do not know the video game, nor have I seen other Street Fighter movies. Obviously, I watched this without a bias. And I thought it was entertaining. The female lead character came across convincingly, so did the villain. In fact, the villain was one of the most engrossing I have seen in a while. I could also enjoy the support characters, they all seemed in tune with the film. The martial arts were not the most impressive I have seen but they were appropriate for an eastern movie. At no point in time did it bother me. I suspect the movie's main issue is it's name which rises expectaions beyond any limit. What a pity in this case.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: Entertaining
review_detailed_main: A little silly at times, especially in scenes with the Chris Kline. He is a stooge. But Kristen is the most perfect little hottie in my lifetime, so to me, it's worth watching. Also the fight scenes are choreographed well for this type of movie.

movie_name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
review_title: just ignore bad comments and enjoy the movie
review_detailed_main: People who do trash talk about the movie are probably video game geeks and big fans of Van Damme's crap Street Fighter stuff. First, this is an origin story of a character so put that in mind. Second it is not a Street Fighter movie so don't expect to see something like Mortal Kombat with a bloody tournament. It is a good written action move which includes the taste of Street Fighter elements. The Movie has a story which is kinda true about Chun Li at some point. Just give it a try and, it is not absolutely perfect but it is not really that bad. In my opinion, it is very good movie to enjoy the night.
